questions.question_text: Which two tasks should be created as functions instead of as procedures? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Reference host or bind variables in a PL/SQL block of code
choices.C: Tasks that compute a value that must be returned to the calling environment
choices.D: Tasks performed in SQL that increase data independence by processing complex data analysis within the Oracle server, rather than by retrieving the data into
choices.B: Tasks that compute and return multiple values to the calling environment

discussion.content: Yes, CD is correct answer here.
Yes, the correct answer is C,D

a function can return multiple values but use the type structure, still the answer is BD

https://asktom.oracle.com/pls/asktom/asktom.search?tag=oracle-function-returning-multiple-values

comments.content: Hi @jcmat : Though a function can return multiple values using a type structure but structure is one entity and we still say functions return only one value in the form of structure.

discussion.content:
This should be BC. 
A function should return value (BC), instead of D- processing data analysis or doing Business Logic.

comments.content: nope, a function must return only one value

discussion.content: Its like Where 1=1, Due to Column name and Variable name being same, In this case SQL considers column.

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C, because the where clause will always return true, since it will only compare the column on the table to itself instead of to the parameter with the same name. Therefore instead of the where cause limiting anything, it will calculate all the rows.
This will return sum of all, rather than just department 60.

choices.D: It gives an error because the variable name and column name are the same in the where clause of the select statement.
choices.A: It gives an error because group functions cannot be used in anonymous blocks.
choices.C: It executes successfully and incorrectly gives the result of the sum of salaries in department 60.
choices.B: It executes successfully and correctly gives the result of the sum of salaries in department 60.
The program executes successfully and the output is No ROWS_FOUND.
choices.C: The program executes successfully and the query fetches a null value in the V_LNAME variable.
choices.A: The program abruptly terminates and an exception is raised.
choices.D: Program executes successfully, fetches a NULL value in the V_LNAME variable and an exception is raised.

discussion.content: Answer is A because implicit cursor expects one record otherwise an error is thrown
I think correct answer is: b)The program executes successfully and the output is No ROWS_FOUND., because I do not see any EXCEPTION SECTION to handle errors.

comments.content: A correct, but they write answer wrong, because we do not raise any exception, Oracle server output error: no data found.

choices.B: There is no effect on procedure A and it runs successfully.
choices.A: Procedure A is invalidated and recompiled immediately.
choices.D: Procedure A is invalidated and recompiles when invoked the next time.
choices.C: Procedure B is invalidated and recompiled again when invoked.

discussion.content:
Opton D is correct
Dependency mode = Timestamp
A is invoking at 1 pm after the last change in B at 11am.
Can someone explain, what would be different in Signature mode...

comments.content: I think D is correct. The A procedure is invalid from 11am to 1pm, than it's invoked and therefore recompiled.

discussion.content: Should be A. invalidation doesn't happen at 1 pm. it happens at 11 and compilation happens at 1.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following scenario:
Local procedure a calls remote procedure B.
Procedure A was compiled at 8 AM.
Procedure A was modified and recompiled at 9 AM.
Remote procedure B was later modified and recompiled at 11 AM.
The dependency mode is set to timestamp.
Which statement correctly describes what happens when procedure A is invoked at 1 PM?

choices.B: It executes and the Output is emprec.deptname: Sales.
choices.A: It executes and the Output is emprec.deptname: .
choices.D: It produces an error because the CHECK constraint is violated while assigning a value to the emprec.deptid field in the record.
choices.C: It produces an error because NULL is assigned to the emprec.empid field in the record.

discussion.content:
A. "The record fields do not inherit the constraints or initial values of the corresponding columns", therefore .empid may be assigned and .deptname value is NULL.
See https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/appdev.112/e25519/composites.htm#LNPLS99912
why execute if a NULL is assigned to the id field?

comments.content: ok maybe because do not inerhit constraints with the %ROWTYPE, self-answer
